wikipedia_page.main: John Tytler (1790–1837) was a Scottish medical officer of the East India Company and orientalist. He was also a significant educator of Indian students in Calcutta.

response: He was born in Munger, the son of John Tytler, an East India Company surgeon.

John Tytler, his son, published Tytler's Miscellanies in Verse (1828) in Calcutta. With it was published a translation of the Punica of Silius Italicus, in two volumes. Included were Tytler's comments on the earlier translation by Thomas Ross (died 1675).Edward L. Bassett, Silius Italicus in England, Classical Philology Vol. 48, No. 3 (Jul., 1953), pp. 155–168, at p. 166. Published by: The University of Chicago Press

Tytler married Christiana Gillies (died 1825), sister of John Gillies. Their children included: Robert Tytler, a surgeon in Bengal; John Tytler (1790–1837), born in Brechin, a medical man and orientalist, mathematics lecturer at the Hindu College from 1831 to 1835; and at least one daughter, Margaret.
